Question: Why do arhats only abide in indeterminate mind and enter parinirvÄá¹‡a?
Answer: Only indeterminate mind accords with the cessation of mind.
That is to say, wholesome mind is strong, enduring, and difficult to destroy, and can cause other minds to continue for a long time.
It does not accord with the cessation of mind.
Indeterminate mind is weak, like rotten seeds, not enduring, and easily destroyed.
It cannot cause other minds to continue for a long time.
Therefore, it is the most conducive to the cessation of mind.
Some say:
Because indeterminate mind has fewer faults when arising.
That is to say, wholesome and unwholesome minds give rise to many faults in the cycle of birth and death through two doors:ğŸ”½First, through the door of the ripening fruit;

The indeterminate mind only gives rise to faults through the power of the homogeneous cause, not through the power of the retribution cause.
Some say:
Because arhats turn their backs on all future rebirths.
That is to say, other sentient beings, when about to die, with the power of extreme attention give rise to a wholesome mind for the sake of future rebirth.
They think, May I not fall into any unfavorable destinies.
Arhats turn their backs on all future rebirths and therefore no longer pay attention.
They simply abide in an indeterminate mind and enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Some say:
Because arhats do not seek to go to the vessel of retribution.
That is to say, other sentient beings, when about to die, give rise to a wholesome mind with extreme effort because they seek to go to the future vessel of retribution.
Arhats, because they do not seek to go to such a vessel of retribution, simply abide in an indeterminate mind and enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.

Because it is never absent in any rebirth.
There may be a single class of sentient beings in which no wholesome minds arise.
This refers to those who have severed wholesome roots and have not yet reconnected them.
There may be a single class of sentient beings in which no unwholesome minds arise.
This refers to those who have already become free from the defilements of the desire realm.
There is no single class of sentient beings in which no indeterminate minds arise.
Therefore, indeterminate minds are called minds of intrinsic nature.
Only abiding in this mind does one enter nirvana.
Some say:

Just as when a person is about to travel to another country, a close friend sees them off. The lower-ranking friend returns to the gate, the mid-ranking friend to the village boundary, and the upper-ranking friend to the national border.

The indeterminate mind is like the above close friend.
